title: fukushima abandoned sega arcade radioactive dust power plant
story: Dutch urban explorer Bob Thissen had to hike through the Japanese ghost town avoiding police patrols to reach the spooky games hall, located deep inside the off-limits section.In contrast to a traditional SEGA Hall, bristling with bright lights and loud sounds to entice gamers, Fukushimas lies silent and sombre yet surprisingly intact.Apart from looted vending and cash machines, the spot still has stacks of tokens, winnable cuddly toys and games galore - but all surfaces are covered in a thin layer of radioactive dust.Bob believes the site, located in the areas forbidden red zone, appears to have remained untouched since the  nuke disaster – which saw over , people flee, leaving homes, belongings and their old lives behind.He said: “It was strange to find a normally vibrant place totally silent and sombre, no lights, visuals or sound.“While I was walking around, I suddenly heard stuffed animals say ‘I Love you.’“It was crazy to see the batteries still worked. I also saw a lot of Disney figures which you could win.“We barely touched anything, because there is radioactive dust.“Its a unique location, because you normally dont get to see a SEGA arcade hall which is fully intact.“I only noticed vending and cash machines were pried open by looters.“Normally they would take out the prizes and sell the arcades. But because of the nuclear disaster everything is left behind.“People fled during the Fukushima disaster and it appears to be in almost the exact same state as it was left.“Soon the whole area will be history. The clean-up and rehabilitation happens really quick and former red zones are coming back to le.“Thats why I think its important to show the real aftermath of the disaster before all traces are gone.”A magnitude nine earthquake – the strongest to ever hit Japan – rocked the region in March , and a subsequent tsunami destabilised the Fukushima nuclear power plant.The spot has remained near-leless ever since, hidden from the outside world behind government exclusion zones – put in place for fear of radiation contamination.Some of the games in the venue included Sonic the Hedgehog, Donkey Kong, House of the Dead, and many more, including toys of Disney characters and talking bears.Bob, who visited the site for his YouTube channel, Exploring the Unbeaten Path, wasn’t surprised by the pristine condition of the games hall. Having visited multiple spots within Fukushima, he believes the people of Japan respect the boundaries put in place, which has helped to preserve it as a near eight-year-old time piece.He said: “I wasnt surprised, because almost everything is left untouched in the forbidden zone.“Everywhere  in the world these buildings would be totally looted after a few weeks.“The Japanese people really respect the rules and never trespass, evendoors are wide open.Bob initially spotted the locations during a trip to the country in , but was unable to reach it.Now having gone back to document the dying remains of Fukushima, he hopes others will respect and appreciate the hall too.Bob added: “We drove by this location in  on route six - at that time the only open road which goes through the red zone - and I really wanted to see it.“But because there was a lot of activity in the red zone - demolition, renovation, radioactive clean-up - we didnt manage to get there.”

title: hannibal lecter fanatic student head hammer eat liver
story: Lawyer Christian Stuenkel, who represents the family of the victim, said the fictional serial killer was the accuseds biggest idol and he watched all the films and series again and again”.The suspect, who was only identied as -year-old Vietnamese student Nhat T., appeared for the first time in the district court of Gera in the German state of Thuringia.Like his hero Lecter, the main character in the series of novels written by Thomas Harris and portrayed onscreen by Anthony Hopkins, Nhat T. was handcuffed as he was led into the courtroom.Lacking Lecters trademark face mask, which covers his mouth and nose, he instead hid his face inside his hoodie.In August , the student, who attended university in the central German city of Jena, gave himself up to cops and reportedly admitted to killing his Chinese classmate Chenxi L earlier the same month.During the trial, the court hopes to find out what Nhat T. did with the body after he allegedly smashed the victims head in with the hammer.Investigators found the body of the Chinese student, , hacked to pieces and stuffed into plastic bags.Some body parts were found by a special ing team in the River Saale while the victim’s head was found under a bridge.Prosecutor Martin Zschaechner confirmed that the victim’s liver was missing from its body and an autopsy showed signs of it being removed by a sharp instrument such as a kne.As the liver was never found, prosecutors believe the suspect might have eaten it given his great fondness of his flesh-munching hero Lecter.Prosecutor Zschaechner said: “The film ‘Hannibal’ definitely played a big role in the defendant’s le. The liver was selectively removed .”The prosecutor was referring to the  Oscar-winning movie The Silence of the Lambs, when the infamous cannibal psychiatrist says his famous line: I ate his liver with some fava beans and a nice chianti.According to the prosecutors, Nhat T. lured Chenxi L. into his student flat by telling him that a package had arrived for him, turning up the music volume and striking him with a hammer.Afterwards, he allegedly hacked the body into pieces in the bath tub.Prosecutors suspect the defendant might suffer from schizophrenia.A mental assessment by a court psychologist has been ordered to find out more about the Vietnamese students state of mind.According to the prosecution, Nhat T. searched for terms such as Hannibal Lecter, secure killing methods and psychological illnesses around , times on the internet before the murder.Before the murder inside student housing accommodation in Jena, the suspect allegedly watched ‘The Silence of the Lambs’ several times and the sequel ‘Hannibal’.Investigators also suspect that the student acted out of greed as he stole the victims computer and mobile phone and ordered expensive goods on the internet using his money.The trial is ongoing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kate feeling broody ireland tour
story: In between cooing over the little one, the Duchess joked that William would be little worried by the arrival of a fourth child.During a wander around Ballymena, Kate was introduced to five-month-old baby James. title: imran khan lothario prime minister nuclear button
story: Posing for a photograph, the then cricketer Imran Khan lounged in his Knightsbridge flat, with a painted tiger on the wall described by one visitor as a bedroom of great expectations.The captain of the Pakistan cricket team - a team that would go on to defeat England in ’s World Cup final - was already known as one of London’s most prolic playboys, one who over the years would be linked with a roll call of glamorous beauties stretching from Hollywood to the aristocracy.Among them were Stephanie Beacham, Goldie Hawn, Kristiane Backer, Susannah Constantine and Marie Helvin – while he also counted no less than Princess Diana as a friend.But then as Khan himself had said meeting women was chief among the very decadent pleasures in le which he enjoyed - and one that led to a bitter row over his paternity of a little girl.Fast forward several decades however, and it is an entirely dferent image that Khan presents to the world.Today Khan is not only the solemn-faced Prime Minister of the country whose cricketing team he once captained, but one with his finger on the nuclear button, and who only today issued a veiled nuclear threat to neighbouring India.Tensions between the two nuclear-armed neighbours have reached boiling point after India carried out air strikes against Pakistani militants yesterday in Balakot - located in a remote valley in Pakistans Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province.During a televised address, Khan asked the chilling question: Can we afford any miscalculation with the kind of weapons that we have and you have.The statement came on a day when both sides had shot down each others warplanes.The Indian strikes followed a suicide bomb attack on February , involving a car packed with explosives, on an Indian security convoy in Pulwama which left  soldiers dead.His we, meanwhile – his third - is a burka-wearing Islamic mystic whose face her husband had never seen before their wedding last year.Maybe the leopard hasnt completely changed its spots as his second we claimed hed had affairs with a string of Bollywood actresses and has illegitimate children by four Indian women.Born to an upper-middle class family in Lahore in , Khan was the only son of a wealthy civil engineer but attended school in Worcester and then Oxford University.It was here that his talent for cricket - he captained the college team and made his test cricket debut - was matched by a talent for attracting female attention.Khan has always denied that he drank alcohol or engaged in any activities that may be considered inappropriate for a conservative Muslim, but there is no doubt that by the late seventies his burgeoning sporting profile was matched by a reputation for non-stop partying at some of London’s most glamorous nightclubs.His preferred venue was Tramp, a hedonistic Mayfair nightspot that Khan frequented so often he referred to it as his living room.A regular in the gossip columns, Marie Helvin - his friend and also his rumoured lover – testied to his magnetism. Everyone falls for Imran,’ she said. He has a scent that is very attractive to women.It proved to be the case for Sita White, daughter of GordonWhite, who was co-founder of the international building materials company Hanson plc.Heiress to her father’s multi-million pound fortune, she met Khan on the dance floor at Tramp and embarked on a relationship which would last, on and off, for the next six years and end in controversy when, in , she bore a child, Tyrian Jade and claimed Khan was the father.Khan’s response  To first ignore her claims and then deny them - although in  a US judge ruled he was the father.By then Khan had long moved on to pastures new in the shapely form of Jemima Goldsmith, another heiress who would become his first we.The daughter of business tycoon Sir James Goldsmith, Jemima was just  to his  when they met in , but the couple were engaged within weeks and duly married in a two-minute Islamic ceremony in Paris followed by a civil ceremony in London.Their honeymoon was more colourful – not in the least because photos of them making love by a swimming pool were circulated among British newspapers although never published.Such was her devotion to her new husband that Jemima converted to Islam and the couple settled in Lahore – where Khan set about trying to shed his playboy reputation, emphasising his respect for Muslim culture.After their marriage ended, in , Khan was rumoured to have enjoyed a short dalliance with Elizabeth Hurley.It was through Jemima – with whom he had two sons, Sulaiman and Qasim – that Khan became friendly with Princess Diana.He later claimed that he had been asked by Diana to act as a marriage broker with heart surgeon Dr Hasnat Khan just three months before her  death.By then his political ambitions were in full swing.In , Khan founded his political party, Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf., although he did not win a seat until , the year his marriage foundered.Over the following years, with his own political star rising, Khan appeared to turn his back on domesticity until, in  he married BBC presenter Reham Khan.The union lasted less than a year, with Khan calling their marriage the “biggest mistake” he had made – a sentiment no doubt fuelled by Khan’s decision to publish a tell-all book in which she made a number of lurid claims about her ex-husband, among them that he believes in black magic and had bedded Bollywood actresses and had children with four other women.The startling revelations seem to have done little to dampen his native country’s enthusiasm for Khan, whose longstanding political ambitions reached their pinnacle last August when he became Pakistan’s nd Prime Minister.He did so with a new we by his side, this time a leading Islamic mystic by the name of Bushra Maneka, from whom Khan had sought spiritual guidance three years earlier.Khan did not see her face until after their wedding — although he had seen a photograph of her as a young woman. In public she remains veiled, while, in the traditional Muslim dress he now favours, Khan is the very image of a sober, conservative politician.It is a world away from the young man who cut a swathe through Londons most beautul women.But then as Khan has frequently said: I never claim to have led an angelic le.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: migration remains at record highs as number of non eu arrivals soars while fewer europeans come after brexit
story: The latest stats from the ONS showed that fewer EU citizens are coming to Britain than any time since , but overall migration numbers are steady.More people came from countries around the world for work and study, leading to the most people coming from outside of the EU since .Meanwhile, EU migration was at its lowest level in a decade at ,, with more EU citizens leaving than coming here.More students are coming than workers too, the data showed.Ministers have said that all EU citizens in the UK should apply to remain after Brexit, but leaving the bloc has left many to leave and travel where.The sliding value of the pound means wages for EU citizens will also be worth less back home too., more people came to the UK than left in the year to September, todays data showed., people in total moved to the UK, but , people left.And separate figures showed the number of EU nationals applying for British citizenship hit an all-time high last year, rising  per cent to around ,.But the PM STILL says shes committed to reducing net migration to the tens of thousands.Jay Lindop, Director of the Centre for International Migration at the ONS said: Due to increasing numbers arriving for work and study, non-EU net migration is now at the highest level since .And Lord Green of Deddington, Chairman of Migration Watch UK, said it was hugely concerning to see that migration remained so high.He said: It is a real concern that non-EU net migration has risen still further to more than a quarter of a million even before the government has implemented its proposals to loosen the work permit system.It’s no surprise that EU net migration has fallen further given the extraordinary uncertainty prevailing over Brexit.Madeleine Sumption, director of the Migration Observatory at the University of Oxford, said: “The overall story the data tell on EU migration is clear: Britain is not as attractive to EU migrants as it was a couple of years ago.Ministers are preparing Britains post-Brexit immigration system ready for when we leave the EU in March.The Government are expected to take another YEAR to make a decision on it.We pay for your stories! title: a happy marriage may depend more on your genes than sharing household chores researchers say
story: They found having one quirk in the gene linked to the “cuddle hormone” oxytocin boosts the odds of a long-lasting relationship.And they believe it could be more important than who does the ironing.One iation is known to make people more sociable, empathetic and emotionally stable.The US study showed relationships are strongestat least one of the partners has this trait.Yale School of Public Health in Connecticut, took saliva from  married, straight couples and quizzed them about their feelings of marital security and satisfaction. Those with the desirable iant were typically happier and more stable.Study leader Dr Joan Monin said: “It seems there may be genetic influences that make it more or less likely for both partners to be  satisfied.”The genetic dference accounted for about four per cent on the scale of marital satisfaction — said to be small but signicant.There were , orces of opposite-sex couples in England and Wales in .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Repairs to the Oldbury Viaduct in the West Midlands have caused misery for drivers over the past two years.But jokey reviews on a Facebook page set up by Highways England to update motorists hail the gridlocked road as a “good day out for the whole family”.Visitor Dan Smith wrote: “We all have memorable moments that have shaped our lives — our first kiss, the birth of our first child, the day we got married.“For me, none compare to the first moment I slowly edged onto junction  of the M and feasted my eyes upon the splendour of the Oldbury Viaduct roadworks.”Others suggest it must be popular given the huge queues.Steven Bartlett said: “Luckily, traffic is that slow moving I get to spend ages taking in the stunning scenery.”The ½-mile viaduct offers views of Oldbury, West Bromwich and Smethwick.Highways England says the project is the biggest concrete repair job yet carried out on Britain’s roads, with more than  miles of scaffolding.Work is due to finish in the spring. GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mps crackdown on landords who turn away workers on benefit
story: It has emerged that half of all private landlords turn away tenants on the handout.They use the phrase ‘No DSS’ on their adverts, after the old name for the Government ministry that supervises it payment.The prejudice makes the search for somewhere to live even harder for the , struggling families who receive it.Housing minister Heather Wheeler told The Sun: “Everyone should have the same opportunity when looking for a home, regardless of whether they are in receipt of benefits.“I will be meeting key stakeholders to tackle “No DSS” advertisements.If the sector is unwilling to take action, the Government will then explore all options to remove this practice.”Homeless charity Shelter, who have campaigned for clampdown on the injustice, welcomed the victory.Polly Neate, chief executive of Shelter, said: “I hope this announcement will send a powerful message to those letting agents, lenders and landlords who still think discriminatory bans are acceptable.“These outdated practices must end.“We look forward to working with the government to make sure that from now on people are treated fairly on a case by case basis.”The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government will also today hand over an extra £.m to councils to help struggling families rent a home.The cash is to be spent on paying deposits or putting down the first months’ rent.One in five of all . million households who live in private rental accommodation receive housing benefit. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: norway 750bn uk investment post brexit future
story: While the UK has spent every penny of its revenues from North Sea oil and gas, like a sailor splashing the cash on their first night back in port, our cousins across the sea have been saving their pennies.For more than  years, Oslo has been putting aside a chunk of that cash and investing it for a rainy day.The result is staggering: A £billion pot — that’s more than £, for every single Norwegian.That’ll buy you a lot of helmets with horns on — and it has helped the ­country avoid a budget deficit, even when times were tough during the ­financial crisis.In other words, Norway is not stupid with money.Having taken the wise decision to save up some of the North Sea windfall, they have worked hard to make it pay.Their national wealth fund is one of the world’s biggest investors and owns shares in , companies spread across  ­dferent countries.So it’s great news that the latest ­decision taken by the fund’s managers is to increase its investment right here, in the UK.The fund has already put ­serious cash into this country.It owns half of the Meadowhall ­shopping centre in Sheffield, and chunks of Regent Street and Oxford Street in ­London. It is a shareholder in hundreds of ­companies, from Greggs and ­Wetherspoons through to Superdry and Moneysupermarket.The UK is already the third-largest destination for this Norwegian investment, and now they’re putting in more.It seems almost surprising, given the endless choruses of woe about Brexit and the pathetic state of our political class in Westminster. Who would want to bet on a country where the job of economic cheerleader is held by Philip Hammond, and the ­alternative is an out-and-out Marxist like John McDonnell The answer is that the Norwegians can see what we sometimes miss about our own country: The UK is a fantastic place to do business.Our legal system is respected around the world for its fairness and is viewed as a “gold standard” under which to sign contracts and do deals.Our corporate taxes are competitive, and are set to fall further. Our location and time zone help to make us a good bridge into markets around the world.Our language is spoken by billions of people, and is the chosen tongue of global business.Our culture is one that still prizes innovation and hard work, despite the best efforts of some Chancellors over the years.And most of all, our people — our greatest asset — are skilled and creative, as employers, inventors and workers alike.It doesn’t come naturally for us to blow our own trumpets and talk ourselves up, so sometimes it feels a bit awkward to ­consider the many things we have going for us.And we all love a good moan, to the degree that it’s essentially a national sport. But we should be careful that we don’t go too far and start to talk ­ourselves down.There’s a dference between being modest and acting like Eeyore with a hangover. Brexit in particular seems to have driven some people a bit loopy, so that you hear some who were once quite ­sensible now ranting about “destroying the country” or “falling off a clf edge”.To hear them, you would think we are a repellent disaster zone, about to slip beneath the waves never to be seen again, like Atlantis crossed with Towie.This is obviously ridiculous. Of course it’s possible that the process of leaving the EU will be dficult.Thanks to politicians who are still ­incapable of honouring their promises and agreeing a clear way forward, the uncertainty about our future ­relationship with our European neighbours has been allowed to drag on for far too long.But it isn’t Brussels, or even Westminster, that made this country wealthy and successful. It is an enterprising approach to le, combining imagination and hard work, that got us this far.Businesspeople and workers, not ­politicians, created the UK’s success.That won’t go away just because we aren’t paying Jean-Claude Juncker’s lunch expenses any more.And once we escape Brussels’ control, we will be free to be even more ­innovative and nimble in response to all the challenges and opportunities the modern age throws at us.The people entrusted with Norway’s £billion national wealth fund can see that. And they aren’t alone.In the latest available data, the UK was Europe’s top destination for foreign investment.Unlike the blowhards and scaremongers chucking out doom and gloom for ­retweets and laughs, these are serious investors, putting their money where their mouth is and betting that our country has a bright future.I know who I’d believe.Norway fund has holdings in:Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cabinet remainers blocking no deal brexit
story: What leverage does he have left in negotiating binding changes to the Irish backstop, now MPs seem prepared to avoid No Deal and postpone Brexit This was all too obvious to Government minister George Eustice who quit yesterday glumly predicting our “final humiliation” and attacking MPs who refuse to respect the referendum result.Remainers Amber Rudd, Greg Clark and David Gauke still insist they do. They will claim their rebellion against Theresa May — a cynical, calculated risk that she is too weak to sack them — was designed to make Brexiteers realise ­voting down her deal could kill Brexit.It may have done that. But it wasn’t lost on Brussels either. And it has severely weakened our hopes of getting the one thing Brexiteers and the DUP need.Cabinet Remainers are guilty both of rank disloyalty and short-sighted stupidity.FOR a shining example of Remoaner madness, witness the negativity to Norway’s huge investment in post-Brexit Britain.Its £billion wealth fund is increasing its UK holdings because, like Qatar, it is sure we will thrive outside the EU.To ex-Labour MP Chris Leslie, though, Norway is just hoovering up our assets on the cheap due to Brexit. Yet he would have been first to blame Brexit had Norway SOLD its UK investments.Some politicians have simply abandoned reason. Their Remainia is religious.THE BBC should be allowed nowhere near its new “BritBox” service.The supposed BBC ITV rival to ­Netflix will require a reported £-a-month subscription. Yet BBC shows are funded by licence-payers. Why should we pay more to see them again ITV’s involvement is fair enough. They’re a private firm. But the BBC loves acting like one, while enjoying a £billion annual bung from TV owners extracted via threat of a criminal record.Why should it be able to deploy that monstrous public subsidy against a brilliant private innovator like Netflix If it wants to compete as a subscription service, fine. But first scrap the licence fee.WE cannot recall a more woeful set of MPs.Yet, without even a vote on it, they will trouser another inflation-beating . per cent pay rise to almost £, a year.That’s  per cent up since . title: emilano sala arranged flight abandonded cardiff city
story: Messages reveal the club offering a flight for the -year-old, which was turned down after Sala said he had arranged his journey with ex-football agent Willie McKay - the man who helped broker the £m deal.The messages produced by French outlet Ouest-France show a Cardf Player Liaison Officer sending a screenshot offering a commercial flight passing through Paris for the striker to take.The messages are in French and Spanish and show Sala declining the offer because he already had a flight arranged after McKay called him.It comes as McKay has accused Cardf City of abandoning Sala.McKay’s son Mark was the Nantes’ acting agent in the deal for the -year-old who died in a plane crash last month.He arranged the flight from Nantes to the Welsh capital when the Piper Malibu crashed into the sea on January , killing Sala and pilot David Ibbotson.McKay told the BBC: “He was abandoned in a hotel more or less to do his travel arrangements himself.”Cardf City say they “strongly reject” the claims they neglected to provide Sala with travel arrangements.In a statement, Cardf said: Our club was in the process of organising a commercial flight for Mr Sala until this offer was declined owing to separate arrangements being made - the planning and specics of which Cardf was not privy to.Cardf has serious concerns over the potential unlawfulness of the journey following information that has been released. Clearly more answers as to the details surrounding this terrible tragedy are required.McKay is not a registered agent but says he got involved in the Sala deal to help his son.McKay also called Cardf City a “disgrace”.He added: Nobody in Cardf seemed to be doing anything. It was a bit embarrassing for Cardf.They buy a player for m euros and then leave him in a hotel by himself to go on the computer and look for a flight - I think Cardf let themselves down badly.The way theyve acted so far, theyve been a disgrace.The Argentine strikers body was recovered from the plane wreckage in the English Channel on February  following a private search launched by his family.An inquest showed he died from head and trunk injuries.Fa is investigating the transfer payment for Sala after his former club has made a claim against Cardf.Cardf have withheld the scheduled initial £.m payment for the player following his death in a private air crash last month.The Welsh side were due to make the payment by February  and then had a later deadline of February , which was extended by a further week.But now Nantes, who owe Bordeaux  per cent of the fee as part of a sell-on clause, have taken the matter to the world governing bodyA Fa spokesman told SunSport: “We can confirm that we have received yesterday evening a claim from FC Nantes against Cardf City in connection with the transfer of Emiliano Sala.“We are looking into the matter and consequently we have no further comments at this stage.”Ibbotson’s body has yet to be recovered from the seabed of the English Channel.His daughter Danielle set up a Go Fund Me page in a bid to secure £, to hunt for her missing dad.She revealed the £, raised by well-wishers was enough to launch the private search.It comes after new pictures of the wreckage were released as the Air Accidents Investigation Branch publishes its interim report into the crash.

title: long lost 129m caravaggio masterpiece unveiled after being found fluke in attic and missed by burglars
story: The work by the Italian master, found five years ago in a farmhouse Toulouse,  was unveiled on Thursday in London after being restored.Titled Judith And Holofernes is due to go on sale in the French city later this year after sitting anonymously against a wall between old clothes, family antiques and crockery.Auctioneer Marc Labarbe burglars broke into the home and stole items including bottles of perfume but left the painting as they thought it worthless.The owners initially believed that the painting was bought by an ancestor who served in the Napoleonic Wars but experts ruled that out.One possibility is that the painting was already in the house when the family bought it in .Speaking at the unveiling of the work at Colnaghi gallery, Mr Labarbe joked the burglars had not deemed the painting adequate enough to steal it.One of my clients was clearing his attic and he needed two men to help him. It took a year to sell all the antiquities.Clocks, toys, pieces of religion, in good and bad condition, clothes, crockery, as well as many things of no interest. Everything was very dusty.I have to tell you that a few years before, burglars broke into the attic and stole many things, included eau de parfum bottles.”Labarbe explained that late one morning in April , late in the morning, the client called him again because he had found a painting and wanted my opinion on it.I went to his house and climbed the stairs to the landing of the attic where the painting was displayed.At this moment there was what was like a fog across the whole canvas.The painting was blurry and it was almost impossible to see the details, but I was impressed by the state of the composition.According to Paris-based art appraiser Eric Turquin, the work was painted in .It depicts the biblical tale of Judith, a widow from the city of Bethulia, who breaks the siege of her home by seducing the Assyrian leader and beheading him.The painting is Caravaggios second version of the same subject, with the first painted in Rome around .The discovery means there are now  known paintings attributed to the artist, who was born in  and died in  of suspected lead poisoning from his paint.

title: spot sleeping owls pench national park india
story: In this picture, snapped in India, these collared scops owls are almost impossible to see as they hide in the tree.The nocturnal animals were so perfectly hidden that Tanay Panpalia almost missed them.The amateur snapper spent  minutes searching to the owls, but eventually managed to spot them.The -year-old saw the roosting owls in the -foot teak tree at Pench National Park in Madhya Pradesh, India.Like birds of a feather, the scop owls can be seen mobbed together and tucked into a hollow in the tree trunk about halfway up.The colouring on their feathers perfectly blends the parliament of owls into the bark.They sleep all day and only come out to fly and hunt for their favourite grub – insects.However, the birds of prey are known to not turn down lizards and mice.In some occasions, they will fall fowl and eat other birds.The collared scops are common in forested and other well-wooded areas in northern India, northern Pakistan, Bangladesh and the Himalayas east to south China.Most commonly found in in South Asia, they nest in trees and lay from three to five eggs.

title: kids miss out secondary school places
story: Around , students in England will fail to get their top choice, analysis by the Good Schools Guide suggests.Anxious parents will find out the outcome by letter from this morning, with a shortage of places expected particularly in big cities and a high demand for the best-performing.An estimated , children applied to start a secondary school in September of this year, a rise of , from .A number of factors may lead to a child being prioritised, and can include entrance exam results, eligibility for  benefits and proximity to the school.Bernadette John, director at the Good Schools Guide said: “Secondary school can be key to unlocking a child’s potential, so no wonder parents are dismayed when the place they get is for an undesirable school.“It has been known for a long time that secondary schools would need to accommodate increased pupil numbers but little action seems to have been taken.“In recent years, some local authorities have struggled to find enough places at primary school level and now we have begun to see the impact on secondary schools.”Parents are asked to list between three and six schools in order of preferences when they applied for the places in October .Last year , children missed out on their first choice - a rise from .Ms John warned parents waiting for results today: “For the next few years, it will get worse.”For further advice on appeals, consult the Coram Children’s Legal Centreor gov.uk schools-admissions appealing-a-schools-decisionPaul Whiteman, general secretary of NAHT headteachers union said there was a desperate need for long-term planning that spans all sectors.“Until the Government sorts its act out and comes up with a national strategy to guarantee there are enough school places for every child in England, the annual anxious wait for families will always be a problem, he said.School Standards Minister Nick Gibb said today was a signicant milestone for thousands of parents and children and maintained standards have risen since .

title: benjamin netanyahu corruption israeli prime minister
story: Charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust are expected to be brought by Israels attorney general in connection with three cases.Mr Netanyahu, who is up for election next month, said in a TV address that the attempt to indict him would collapse like a house of cards.He is accused of accepting luxury gts - including cigars, pink champagne and jewellery worth ,from Hollywood film producer Arnon Milchan and the Australian billionaire James Packer.Mr Milchans gts were allegedly infor help with a US visa and tax breaks.Both Mr Milchan and Mr Packer denied any wrongdoing and face no charges.But the embattled Israeli PM also faces two more cases linked to charges of fraud and breach of trust after allegedly trying to get more favourable press coverage for himself.More damaging are accusations he struck deals with Israli media mogul Shaul Elovitch, who owns the countrys largest telecom company Bezeq.Infor positive coverage on an Elovitch-owned news site Mr Netanyahu allegedly made regulatory promises worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the media tycoon.Mr Elovitch, who himself faces a legal battle, strongly denied wrongdoing, however police said their investigation concluded the two men engaged in a bribe-based relationship.The charges are set to be brought by Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit.In a defiant broadcast to the nation the prime minister claimed to be the victim of a left-wing witch-hunt that had been timed to topple him as the election on  April approaches.He said: said: The left knows it cannot beat us at the polling booth, so for the past three years they have been carrying out an unprecedented witch hunt which has one aim - to topple the right-wing government which I lead.A final hearing likely to take place after the election will determine whether the charges go forward.Mr Netenyahu and his we have faced similar corruption charges over the past three years.In June last year his spouse Sara Netanyahu was charged with fraud for allegedly misusing , in public funds to order lavish meals from Israels most famous chefs.US President Donald Trump, a close friend of Mr Netanyahu, offered the Israeli leader a boost ahead of the expected announcement.He said at a press conference yesterday: “I just think he’s been a great prime minister and I don’t know about his dficulty but you tell me something people have been hearing about, but I don’t know about that.“I can say this: that he’s done a great job as prime minister. He’s tough, he’s smart, he’s strong,”

title: scarlet fever cases sore symptoms
story: The disease, which used to kill large thousands back in the th century, is on the rise - particularly among kids.Its a seasonal illness thats most common around this time of year.The latest report by Public Health Englandshowed that , cases of scarlet fever have been reported since mid-September , with  cases reported last week.Its usually quite a mild illness that can be easily treated with antibiotics but is incredibly contagious.The infection can be prevalent for up to seven days before the symptoms start and it can remain highly infectious for two weeks after symptoms begin without a course of antibiotics.If you think that your child might have scarlet fever, then you need to contact your GP  or ring NHS .While scarlet fever is easily treatable, it really just depends on how early you catch it.Leaving it too late can lead to much more serious complications, such as pneumonia - an illness which kills more kids than any other disease in the UK.If you or your child has it, you need to stay at home for at least  hours after starting the antibiotic treatment, so that you dont spread it to other people.Dr Theresa Lamagni, Senior Epidemiologist at Public Health England, said: “It’s not uncommon to see a rise in cases of scarlet fever at this time of year.But when they do kick in, they can include:Scarlet fever is contagious but not usually serious and can be treated with antibiotics to reduce the risk of complications and spread to others.We are monitoring the situation closely and remind parents to be aware of the symptoms of scarlet fever and to contact their GP for assessmentthey think their child might have it.She said that PHE is investigating possible reasons for why theres been a rise in scarlet fever cases over the past few years.Professor Helen Stokes-Lampard, Chair of the Royal College of GPs, said: “Patients with scarlet fever usually present with flu-like symptoms including a sore throat, fever and headache, as well as a characteristic rosy rash - usually on the patient’s chest initially.“Scarlet fever is a bacterial infection that generally affects children under  more than teenagers or adults.It is very contagious but can be quickly and effectively treated with a full course of antibiotics.GPs would also recommend patients to rest, drink plenty of fluids, and use antihistamine tablets or calamine lotion for relief of symptoms related to the rash.“We have seen more cases of scarlet fever in the last few years than we’ve been used to – we’re unsure why this is, butpatient thinks that they, or their child, might have symptoms, then they should seek medical advice.”According to the NHS, your GP can often tellsomeones got the infection simply by looking at the tongue and rash.While the antibiotics theyll prescribe wont cure scarlet fever, theyll stop you from being infectious within  hours and will make you less likely to develop something like pneumonia.

title: queen picture purple hand official snap
story: The -year-old monarch yesterday hosted King Abdullah, Queen Rania and Crown Prince Hussein of Jordan at Buckingham Palace, and was seen smiling cheerfully for the snap in a ivory white, three-quarter sleeved dress.But sharp-eyed royal fans were concerned to see Her Majestys left hand was a dark purple colour as she co-hosted the event with her daughter, Princess Anne.Tracy Edgar tweeted: Im concerned. title: car thief given community service and debt written off
story: Daniel Moult, , stole a £, VW Polo car during a raid in Rossendale, Lancs.Owner Barbara White said the crime had been “devastating “and had left her feeling “anxious and violated”.But Moult and his accomplice Kyle Livesey, , will serve no time in prison and were ordered to pay back just £ each - over £ less than the value of the car.The pair, who have  offences between them, were also told they can pay it back at £-a-week as they’re on benefits - meaning it will take them two years to clear.Moult, who sold the car for just £, even had a £ debt for a previous debt written off because he can’t afford it.When the sentence was read out at Burnley magistrates’ court, shameless Moult, who was already on licence from jail when he stole the car on August  last year, commented: “Nice one.”Later Livesey posted on Facebook: “Absolutely buzzin wid result in court yesteday. Got a top result!”Moult escaped with just a slap on the wrist after his probation officer told the court: “He says he won’t do unpaid work as it would do his head in. He will do a curfew.”Moult, of Bacup, Lancs, and Livesey, of Manchester, were caught on CCTV taking the victim’s car from private land in a rural area of Rossendale, at around .pm last August .Mrs White has not received a penny from her insurers as the vehicle was unlocked and the keys were in it.In a statement she read to the court, Mrs White said: “”The financial impact has been great as I couldn’t claim anything at all.”Beth Pilling, prosecuting, said the men had arrived earlier in the day with two women but were asked to leave. They then ed later that evening.Miss Pilling said: “She indicates the keys had been left in the vehicle under the floor mat. She thought it was safe. The vehicle was unlocked.“The vehicle has never been found and she has had to buy another.”JPs had earlier announced the offence was so serious it crossed the custody threshold - before imposing suspended sentences.The pair, who admitted theft of a motor vehicle, were both given eight weeks in prison, suspended for a year, with ten-day rehabilitation activity requirement.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains favourite pies revealed your
story: NewsBritains favourite pies revealed - is your choice in the top  A new study has found the amount of pies scoffed by the average Brit in their letimeShareCommentsBySiân Yates:,  FEB NewsFood artist Prudence Staite creates iconic scenes and depictions from around the UK – made entirely from pies "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe average Brit scoffs a whopping , pies over their adult letime, according to a study. The research, which polled , adults, found pie enthusiasts consume a huge amount of pastry over the years, chowing down on at least  pies every year. It also emerged the nation’s favourite pie is the classic beef and ale, but proving we still have a sweet tooth, apple pie came in second place. This was closely followed by chicken and mushroom and steak and kidney pie, with lemon meringue revealed as another of the our favourite dessert pies.   The research was commissioned by Jus-Rol to celebrate the start of British Pie Week which is between the th and th of March. To mark the occasion Jus-Rol teamed with food artist, Prudence Staite, to create iconic scenes and depictions from around the UK – made entirely from pies. The series of seven art pieces which took  painstaking hours to make and place , inidually handmade cooked and uncooked pies per image used a whopping  kg of Jus-Rol Shortcrust, Puff and Filo pastry. Spokeswoman for Jus-Rol, Holly Bouldin, said: “The humble beef and ale pie has been a true British classic for as long as we can remember, but it’s surprising to see some dessert pastries so high up in the list. “Other British pie classics – including chicken and mushroom, beef mince and chicken and leek – also made the list of melt-in-your-mouth fillings.   “The research shows that whether sweet or savoury, Brits can enjoy a good pie during any occasion – and it turns out very few would turn down the chance to eat one of these tasty pastry dishes.” The study, carried out by One Poll, also found that Northern Ireland chomps its way through more pies than anyone  in Britain, with one in  consuming six pies every month, compared to a national average of three per month. They are followed by Londoners and those in the North East as the most avid pie eaters, with one in seven eating four pies a month in both areas.  When it comes to dusting off the rolling pins and making pies at home, Northern Ireland came out on top – baking on average two pies a month. However,  per cent admitted they don’t even use a rolling pin – with one in  opting for a wine bottle to smooth out their pastry. Many Brits even go free-style and simply use their hands to stretch out that pastry, with one in  from the South West most likely to adopt this method.  Other popular, ingenious alternatives to the rolling pin include fizzy drinks cans, milk bottles, thermos flasks and even tall drinking glasses. Bouldin said: “Founded back in  by Jus-Rol, British Pie Week aims to inspire the nation to celebrate one of the greatest British classic foods. We wanted to pay tribute to that love by creating images out of pies that reflect ious areas of the UK.” “And these survey results reveal the true depth of the nation’s feelings towards pies. I’m astounded by the amount of pie we do actually eat, particularly the Northern Irish.”Jus-Rol are running a contest to challenge the country to bake the iconic flavours and ingredients of their region into a newly created pie. To enter, send an image and the recipe to www.jusrol britishpieweek for a chance to win pound,. Competition closes at midnight on Sunday th March.The nation’s favourite pie:Beef and Ale Apple Chicken and Mushroom Steak and Kidney Lemon Meringue Beef mince Apple and Blackberry Chicken and Leek Chicken and ham hock Beef and Red Wine

story: NewsClothing chain Gap is closing more than  stores as company splitsGap has a number of stores in the UK, but the closures are worldwide and it hasnt been announced as to which branches will be affectedShareCommentsByRyan WilkinsonSam Rkaina:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsThe brand is the latest high street icon to take a hit "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHigh street clothing stalwart Gap is closing more than  stores as part of a worldwide restructuring programme. The retailers San Francisco-based parent company, Gap Inc, is splitting into two companies, one of which will consist of the eponymous brand and others including Banana Republic. A second company will solely house its Old Navy brand, which has been out-performing its stablemates. The company has not said where shops will shut or how many jobs will be affected, although all  closures over the next two years will be of Gap stores. story: NewsCouple sues former owner of £k flat as theyre forced to flee violent neighbourMichelle Smith and Jason Stevens were subjected to a "violent outburst" by their next-door neighbour days after moving into the property near Sutton, south LondonShareCommentsByBradley Jolly:,  FEB NewsMichelle Smith and Jason Stevens took their case to Central London County Court "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A young couple have sued the man who sold them their first home after he failed to warn them about a violent and aggressive next-door neighbour .Michelle Smith, , and Jason Stevens, , claim they had to flee the two-bed flat with their baby on their first weekend there as their neighbour had a violent outburst. He allegedly caused thousands of pounds worth of damage to the front door of the flat near Sutton, south London, which the couple bought for pound, in . They were then told by police it was unsafe for them to live there with their young son, they say. Now Michelle and Jason have sued vendor and former occupant Christopher Flynn for thousands of pounds.   Central London County Court had the dispute down for a trial but a decision was quickly made today that Mr Flynn must cough up.The court was heard Mr Flynn knew the aggressive violent tendencies of his neighbour, but failed to disclose it in pre-sale documents.Lawyers for the couple said in court documents: On the first weekend after completion,  June , whilst Ms Smith and Mr Stevens were in the property preparing for redecoration, Mr Stevens, his stepfather and mother were subjected to a violent outburst.   The police attended the scene and the general advice given to the couple, in the light of having an infant son, was not to live in the property until it was safe to do so. The court heard the couple claimed thousands in compensation for distress and inconvenience, repair of their door, and costs related to accommodation and mortgage payments while they say they were unable to live there. But Mr Flynns lawyers denied he acted dishonestly or that the neighbours behaviour was his responsibility after he moved out. Their court documents read: It is admitted that there was a dispute between Mr Flynn and his former neighbour, but that this was a dispute which had ended circa one year and a half prior to marketing the property.   The dispute by the neighbour against Mr Flynn was personal to Mr Flynn...following resolution of the dispute there were no further issues. It is not admitted that Mr Flynn ly completed the property forms or that he denied the existence of such issues with the neighbour. It is not accepted that Mr Flynn misrepresented the sale....It is also not admitted that the alleged representations were made in order to induce Mr Stevens and Ms Smith to enter into contract to purchase the property.

title: david lammys right stacey dooley
story: NewsopinionAxe Stacey Dooley-style poverty porn and show us the truth about AfricaThe Labour MP has slammed the Strictly winner for acting like a "white saviour" in her recent Instagram postsShareCommentsByEva Simpson:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsopinionStacey has been to Africa for Comic Relief"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShack with corrugated iron roof, tick. Impoverished, braless women dancing and clapping in a circle, tick. Nervous looking child in dirty, torn clothes balanced on your hip, tick. Well done Stacey Dooley , you’ve managed to tick every Poverty Porn clicheacute in the book on your trip to Uganda for Comic Relief. I have no doubt the Strictly Come Dancing champion meant well with her Instagram snaps in which she breathlessly tells us she’s “OB.SESSSSSSSSSSED” with the nameless little boy she’s clutching while wearing designer clothes. CRINGE!   But David Lammy is right, it’s both patronising and condescending to the people they’re trying to help and I’m glad he’s called her out for acting like a “white saviour” who’s perpetuating “tired and unhelpful stereotypes”. Comic Relief has a huge  and privilege and it’s the first major way children learn about Africa,” he said. “If they only show Africans as helpless victims to be pitied, children missed the broader picture of huge progress in Africa.” How can anyone disagree with this  Dooley weakly hit back at the politician saying: “You could always go there and try to raise awareness ”   In fact he’s been asked but he said no because he was didn’t want to become “part of a PR exercise”. Instead of launching an attack on Lammy, Dooley and Comic Relief should listen to what he has to say. Like David, I too feel deeply uncomfortable with this tired negative narrative that portrays Africa as a nation of starving, helpless people waiting for white people to come and save their lives. Throwing money at men, women and children is not to only way to help. For example, Comic Relief could save thousands of pounds on travel expensesthey used local camera crews, producers and editors.   This way they would be giving jobs to people to provide for themselves and their families. As someone who regularly goes to Ghana, west Africa, I can tell you the pictures of starving children covered in flies and living on rubbish dumps are not one that I see. In fact that’s one of the reasons AfroBeats artist Fuse ODG turned down Bob Geldof’s request to take part in the Band Aid  – he was frustrated with how negatively the lyrics portrayed Africa. I see a country undergoing rapid transition, incredible growth and one with a very bright future. If you’re planning a holiday, I can’t recommend it highly enough. Sometimes I think it has more going for it that Brexit Britain right now. While Comic Relief has done an amazing job in raising money and awareness it needs to change the record we need to hear more balanced stories about Africa, which, by the way is a continent, not a one country. Can we at least get that right

story: NewsFour hour AE target to be scrapped within a year despite warning from doctorsMedics have previously warned that ditching the target could have a near catastrophic impact on patient safetyShareCommentsBySam Rkaina:,  MAR NewsThe target has not been hit in nearly four years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe four-hour AE target in hospitals is reportedly set to be scrapped within a year. NHS England is backing the plans, The Times reported, with sources telling the paper chief executive Simon Stevens wants to introduce a change over the coming year. The Government has previously said it plans to ditch the target for % of patients to be seen at AE within four hours. Instead, those with less serious illnesses could have to wait longer, while new targets may be brought in for conditions such as heart attacks and stroke. NHS England said no final decision had yet been made and any changes would be tested before being implemented from October. Doctors have previously warned that getting rid of the target would have a near-catastrophic impact on patient safety. Emergency units have not hit the target since July .   Professor Stephen Powis, NHS national medical director, said: The clinically-led review of standards was announced by the Prime Minister in June . Since then I have been working with the Academy of Medical Royal Colleges, Healthwatch England and many others on what matters most to patients, on the clinical issues with the current target regime, and what NHS staff believe will help them provide the best quality care for patients. Any recommended changes will be carefully field tested across the NHS, before they are implemented. A Department of Health and Social Care spokeswoman said: As part of the ongoing Clinical Standards Review, the NHS is reviewing performance standards to ensure patients with the most serious illness and injury receive the best possible care in the shortest possible timeframe. The NHS is working closely with clinical experts and patient groups nationally and will set out proposals in due course.

title: guide dogs new tear jerking
story: NewsGuide Dogs new tear-jerking advert aims to shatter peoples misconceptionsEXCLUSIVE: The sweet advert focuses on the relationship between a father and daughter played by ‘dad’ Alex Pepper and his daughter eight-year-old Xanthe Lebus-SmithShareCommentsByLiz Dunphy:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video advert-guide-dogs-leaves-viewers-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeet the stars of the Guide Dogs new tear-jerking advert which aims to shatter peoples misconceptions about sight loss. Narrated by Dame Julie Walters, the advert focuses on the relationship between a father and daughter played by ‘dad’ Alex Pepper and his daughter eight-year-old Xanthe Lebus-Smith. In the advert Xanthe describes her every move in a football match she is playing in as Alex stands pitchside with other parents – an everyday scenario that many people will be familiar with. During the match she shouts out: “I’m over here dad, on the wing. “Dad, I’m tackling. I’m running. “I did a header. I got the ball, dad. “I’m going to shoot, dad.” But she just misses the goal and looks sad.   The advert cuts to the father and daughter holding hands as they walk away from the park and she tells him: “I was really close, dad.” The camera pans up to reveal that her dad is blind as he tells her with a big smile: “I know sweetheart. I think you were brilliant out there today.” The advert, which will premiere on ITV at .pm during Dancing on Ice on Sunday, aims to sht public sympathy for those with sight loss into empathy and further understanding of the realities of le with little or no sight. It comes as research shows that people with sight loss do not feel that wider society understands the challenges they face, with many feeling ‘left out’ of everyday le and milestone le moments. It also reflects an evolution of its brand positioning to become more people-centred and move beyond its well-loved dogs. Alex, , a former Met Police emergency call handler who lost his eyesight in , said that his own personal experience reflects that research. He developed retinoblastoma, a rare form of eye cancer, as a baby and had an eye removed at  months.  The cancer recurred in his other eye, aged , but after treatment his vision was quite stable from his mid-teens until , when one morning everything changed. He remembers: I had about % - % vision before . It made some things dficult but I could still get around on my own. My vision had been stable for years so it was a huge shock when I woke up one morning and there was a shadow in the corner of my eye. I was panicky and scared but I thought it was a detached retina which could be operated on. But at an emergency appointment that afternoon my surgeon, who had successfully operated on me before, told me that I had too much scarring already in my eye and poor blood supply so they could not operate.   Then, between January, , and May, , my sight deteriorated until all I had left was light perception at best. It was a very dficult time. I realised that sight loss was like losing a loved one. You grieve. Youre never going to get over it but you can learn to get on with it. Its made me reflect on whats important in le. Once you cant see anymore, you realise how much you used to focus on things that actually dont matter. I talk to people in the street now who I probably wouldnt have spoken to before, and people speak to me who probably would not have approachedI didnt have a cane or a dog.  Its like you see no evil. Thats a real silver lining. Before, I was always trying to hide my sight loss. To fit in as much as I could. Like when I went through Victoria train station in London every day for work. I was too proud to use a magnier to check the train times on my phone app or ask the staff for help. But I knew that every train on two s would go to my stop. So I would see which  people were rushing to more and I would follow them to that train. It worked but it was hugely stressful. But now Ive lost that fear and I can go anywhere with my dog and ask for help. So in a weird way its been a relief. Sight loss has taken down so many barriers that I put up for myself in the first place.  But Alex has noticed how people sometimes treat him dferently now and he believes this stems form a misunderstanding of disability. He said: Like at a train station,I have passenger assistance and staff members are bringing me from one place to another, staff will ask each other wheres he going  when Im standing right there. I tell them myself where Im going with a smile and people can seem quite surprised when they realise that although I have a guide dog I can still speak for myself. Im not a blind person, Im just a person who happens to be blind. Theres nothing very dferent about me, it just happens that I cant see.   People can get uncomfortable around disability because they have not had the conversations before but I hope this campaign can open peoples eyes to the fact that people with sight-loss can live a normal le. “Its weird, since Ive had my amazing guide dog River Ive been asked directions a lot more than I ever had before in central London. My friends laugh that people ask a blind person for directions, but the really funny thing is that I always know where to direct them.” Alex worked for the Met police for four and a half years as a communications officer, handling emergency calls. However, after losing the majority of his eye sight, he joined national sight loss charity, London Vision, as project co-ordinator. He has a step daughter, , and a niece, , both of whom are obsessed with his guide dog, River. He is getting married in May, so he and his fianceacutee are in the thick of wedding planning.  He said: My fianceacutee and I are planning our wedding at the moment. People always talk about that moment when a man sees his bride walk down the aisle. Ill never have that but my fianceacutee, friends and family are making sure Im included in other ways. When we were visiting venues I couldnt get the wow factor anywhere because I couldnt see them. But then we walked into one venue with a lake and a water feature. There was this other sensory experience. I could hear the water and the place just felt so tranquil and I loved it. Luckily my fiancee did too – she was in tears she liked it so much so we chose to marry there. We had only been together for six or seven months when I lost my al vision. It was a very, very dficult time but she went through it all with me. She has been amazing. “I noticed the other day just how well my six-year-old step-daughter has adapted to my sight loss too. I asked a friend how she was with a question and when her friend nodded in reply, she immediately said, shes nodding yes.  I was waiting on a phone call from the Guide Dogs saying they might have a dog for me for months. It was my last step to freedom. Id call them every day asking. When the call came and I went to meet my amazing guide dog River I was more nervous than Id ever been in my le. Excuse the pun but it was like a blind date. I knew that every match does not work. I was sitting in the room, waiting for them to bring River in, heart pounding, sweating, and River came in, snfed me and lay at my feet. His trainer said I think he likes you. And that was it. River has changed my le. Guide Dogs made me realise that help is out there. If you suffer sight loss, take advantages of the resources available – reach out to organisations, family and friends. You can get there on your own but youll succeed  times faster with help. Fundraise There are many ways you can get together to raise money for Guide Dogs. From hosting your own tea party to pushing yourself in a challenge event, find out how you can make a dference as a Guide Dogs fundraiser. Donating Every hour, someone in the UK starts to lose their sight. Help us make sure they don’t lose out on le by making a donation today. Find out more about the many ways you can donate to Guide Dogs, including cash donations and sponsoring a puppy. Volunteering for Guide Dogs Want to give some time to making a real dference  You could give five minutes, five days or more. Find out how you can help by volunteering at Guide Dogs. Campaigning We campaign for the rights of people with sight loss so that they can enjoy better access to public transport, our town centres and other services. You can help us to get our messages across. Rehoming a guide dog Information on adopting a retired or withdrawn guide dog, rehoming frequently asked questions, and joining the waiting list for either a retired or a withdrawnguide dog. How your company can get involved Ways to support us - choose Guide Dogs as your corporate partner. Working alongside Alex to get out the important message was Xanthe. The young aspiring actor, soccer-player and dog-trainer said: “My favourite part of the ad was talking to Alex. He made me laugh a lot and he told me about his guide dog River. I told him about our puppy Ziggy too who is not as well-behaved as River.” But Xanthe said that River inspired her to train up Ziggy to be as good as River one day and she learned other lessons from their interaction too. She said: “I learned that when you see someone with a guide dog you should not touch it without asking the owner first because the dog is working and it will get distractedyou touch it. Ive told all my friends at school that now. Guide Dogs offers services including sighted guiding, online and childrens and young peoples services, but the charity’s research has shown it is only really known for canine services. The charity aims to reach and support many more iniduals of all ages and their families with le-changing services – from , today to , by  through its strategy ‘By My Side’. Emma Foulds, Director of Marketing, Digital and Influencing at Guide Dogs, said: “This exciting campaign is our first that brings to le our ambitious ‘By My Side’ strategy, with the aim to support , people with sight loss by . Our research has shown that there’s a need to sht the conversation around sight loss away from sympathy towards empathy and encouragingly it appears the public would like to join us on that journey.”For more information, see www.guidedogs.org.uk

title: hair transplant doc reveals celebs
story: NewsHair transplant doc reveals celebs whove had secret surgery - including Oscars starThe number of men having hair transplants has tripled thanks to stars like Wayne Rooney, Shane Warne and Jack P ShepherdShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB NewsDr Bessam Farjo is a leading hair restorative surgeon "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTen years ago it was something men would never have talked about let alone decided to do anything about.But now the final male taboo - baldness - has finally been smashed and more men than ever are opting for hair transplants . High profile patients like Wayne Rooney, cricket legend Shane Warne and Coronation Street star Jack P Shepherd have planted the once secret surgery firmly out in the open.The number of hair transplants has almost triped since  when just , were carried out. In  a total of , people opted to go under the kne to have their hair restored.   But it would seem some chaps are still not comfortable to admit when theyve undergone the innovative op. Dr Bessam Farjo has clinics in both Manchester and London and is one of the leading hair restoration surgeons. Speaking tohe said: There are people in the spotlight who its agreed have had some work done.In my opinion Bradley Cooper has had some very good work done on his hairline.I say the same of Sylvester Stallone and Mel Gibson.   John Travolta, I dont believe, has had any work done but he wears a lot of hair pieces and wigs and has recently been pictured with a shaved head. Dr Farjo believes the huge rise in the number of men opting to have the surgery, which costs around pound, in the UK, is down to a breakdown in stigma. He explained: The rise, in part, has been driven by celebrities and the general public being open about what they’ve had done. Terms like metrosexual are a little old hat now, but what began with that trend has led to procedures like this becoming more commonplace today. We are looking after ourselves more, and there is less stigma around men taking pride in their appearance.  If men don’t like something about their body, and they see ‘normal blokes’ like Wayne Rooney, James Nesbit or Shane Warne doing it, they thing ‘why not ’ And the rise in the success - and the reduction in cost - of hair transplants has also helped to break down the stigma. But the surgeon insists hair loss, or male pattern baldness, is not on the increase. More than a third of men have some kind of hair loss by the time theyre , and up to half of blokes aged . There are two manin types of transplant surgery.  The first involves surgeons reoving inidual hair follicles from the scalp using punches. The the surgeon makes microscopic slits in the receiving area of the patient’s scalp, and the inidual grafts will be placed into these sites by the doctor and his team. This is popular because it doesnt leave a hairline scar, instead just tiny dot scars. The treatment can take up to  hours and can involve , grafts in a single day. Hair starts to grow about four months after surgery and will keep growing for the next  to  months. The second involves using a thin strip skin with hair on it from somewhere  on the scalp known as the permanent area.  This is where hairs are genetically programmed to keep growing for le. It had to be done under local anaesthetic and uses high-powered microscopes to dissect the healthy hair follicles and transplant them into the area affected by hair loss. The surgery can take up to  hours and again it can take the hair four months to start to grow. But there can be risks when it comes to hair transplants, especially when people opt for a cheaper transplant abroad. Dr Farjo explained: There’s a growing number of ‘unethical’ hair restoration clinics — both here in the UK and abroad — mostly operated by non-doctors. In the worst of cases, patients attending these run the risk of becoming disfigured with an unnatural looking hairline or wasting priceless donor hair for future use.  However, we hear procedures can be sourced for as little as pound from some clinics, with many cheap operators typically located in Turkey. That may sound tempting, but it really isn’t worth the risk. In the UK, any clinic offering a hair transplant surgery must register with the Care Quality Commissionand will therefore be inspected. If a doctor operates on a patient in a non-CQC registered hair transplant clinic then they are breaking the law. Additionally, doctors in the UK must abide by strict ethical guidelines set by the General Medical Council , and must be covered by regulated liability insurers. If they breach this guidance, a patient can report them to the GMC.

title: half motorists want clean air
story: NewsHalf of motorists want Clean Air Zones – eventheyre charged for entering themThe Clean Air Zones scheme is part of the Government’s Air Quality Plan, announced in July ShareCommentsByRob Knight:,  FEB NewsLondon already has its own Ultra Low Emission Zone which from th April will see higher polluting vehicles charged £. a day to enter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHalf of motorists are in favour of Clean Air Zones – eventhey were charged for entering them, a study found. Birmingham and Leeds are among the cities set to introduce the zones to improve air quality in those areas - potentially requiring drivers to pay a fee. The Clean Air Zones scheme is part of the Government’s Air Quality Plan, announced in July , which aims to reduce pollution and make the air cleaner throughout the UK. London already has its own Ultra Low Emission Zone which from th April will see higher polluting vehicles charged pound. a day to enter. Commissioned by Hitachi Capital UK, the research of , UK adults found around a third think there is a particularly signicant problem with pollution where they live. And eight in  think urgent action needs to be taken to reduce emissions.   Jon Lawes, managing director of Hitachi Capital Vehicle Solutions, said: “Despite the potential dent to our wallets, the research shows there is signicant support for charging schemes that tackle pollution in our major towns and cities. “It’s clear those polled believe something needs to be done – and fast.” The research also found half of motorists polled admit they are ‘too reliant’ on their car. In fact, the car is the number one way Brits get to work– miles ahead of public transportand foot . Further to this,  per cent agree we should make greater use of public transport and leave our vehicles at home more often. Six in  also believe the move towards electric vehicles is a good thing but just  per cent have owned or currently do own one. Those polled reveal free charging ports and more of them, reassurances over how long the battery lasts and greater financial incentives would encourage them to get an electric vehicle. Despite the positivity surrounding the introduction of clean air zones, previous attempts to reduce emissions and congestion have had mixed results according to those polled.   Seventy-nine per cent believe bus lanes have made no dference to the number of cars on the road. Eight in  think car share lanes have had no impact on air quality – and  per cent think the same goes for cycle lanes. Despite this, the Hitachi Capital UK research carried out through OnePoll found support for Clean Air Zones is so strong a third think it would be ‘fair’companies pass any additional costs on to customers. Jon Lawes added: “Whilst it’s very encouraging that the poll shows more and more drivers see alternative fuel vehicles as the long-term solution to reducing air pollution where other schemes haven’t worked, these findings highlight the obstacles that still need to be overcome to persuade drivers to truly embrace greener alternatives. “Although the pound million scrappage incentive scheme recently announced to help Londoners is welcome, both private and business vehicle owners are facing financial pressure in upgrading to greener options in the short term. “Our own research has found that the migration to alternative fuels could deliver fuel cost savings running into billions of pounds for vehicle owners, whilst advances in alternative fuel vehicle performance and infrastructure are certainly changing driver perceptions. “So while there may be a short-term cost to consumers and businesses, by encouraging people to invest in greener vehicles, the benefits in the long term will be signicant, not only financially but environmentally too.”

title: ponies gorge rubbish left out
story: NewsNew Forest Ponies gorge on rubbish in street after council rejects wheelie binsThe flimsy black sacks attract the wild ponies who devour the contents in the village of Bransgore, New Forest, HampshireShareCommentsByJack Williams:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThere are fears the famous animals that roam the Hampshire National Park could be ingesting dangerous plastics and poisonous foods "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the distressing sight of a herd of New Forest ponies gorging on rubbish left out in the street. There are fears the famous animals that roam the Hampshire National Park could be ingesting dangerous plastics and poisonous foods on a regular basis. The local council does not operate a wheelie bin system and so homeowners have to leave out bin bags for collection. But the flimsy black sacks attract the wild ponies who devour the contents. The troubling photographs, taken in the picturesque village of Bransgore, show the creatures feasting on the contents of the black bags.   In one image, a pony is seen nose-deep in a pile of rubbish, with a number of Carlsberg beer cans strewn across the ground. In another four of the animals are depicted munching on nine bin bags left against a garden fence. Villagers have accused New Forest District Council of putting the ponies at risk by not issuing wheelie bins. Local resident Kate White: Its really sad that this carries on week after week. I regularly come across ponies and donkeys eating rubbish at the side of the road.   I have notied the council about it three times already and they say they will pass it on to the refuse team. But its disappointing because the council doesnt do anything about it. I dont know why residents dont have wheelie bins. Ponies have roamed the New Forest for thousands of years, pre-dating the last ice age. Today they are owned by commoners - landowners who have ancient rights to allow animals to graze on the forest - and have free rein around the woodland.  The current population stands at about , and continue to be a major attraction to tourists. New Forest District Council said that keeping rubbish away from the ponies was the responsibility of homeowners, not them. On its website, the council states: Your rubbish is your responsibility before it has been collectedanimals do split the bags then you are responsible for clearing it up. A council spokesperson added: We are aware that this is sometimes an issue in this area. We are clearing the rubbish and will be reminding residents to keep their sacks inside their gates, as they live where there are free-roaming animals, and not to put rubbish out before pm the evening before collection.
