Its a scenario that thousands of students will face when offers are emailed out, with a recent study finding one in five children will not be able to attend their preferred school. A majority do get their first choice, but what should you doyour child doesnt and you are unhappy about it    Parents can file an appeal to have the decision overturned. Here is some advice on how to do that. How to appeal Parents can challenge the decision through a formal appeal process with the admission authority - the local council or the school itself. The first step is to accept the place their child has been given, eventhey dont want it. Parents who dont accept the spot and appeal could leave their child without a school when the new year starts in September, as local authorities do not have to offer an alternative.Appeals can be filed with each school named on the preference form. So,a child is given their third choice, his or her parents orcan appeal to their first and second choice schools. Details on the appeal process are supposed to be included in the letter with the decision. They can also be obtained from the admission authority, usually on the local council or schools website.Parents can also check the Governments School Admission Appeals Code.Provide strong evidence   Parents who appeal the decision must provide strong evidence in writing explaining why their child should be given a spot at their preferred school. In recent years, only a quarter of appeals were successful. Potential grounds for appeal can include admission procedures being wrongly applied or potential harm to a child. Families must appeal against each rejection separately and can only appeal once against each rejection. What is the timeline  The admission authority for the school must allow at least  school days to appeal from when they send the decision letter, the Government says. It adds: The admission authority will set a deadline for submitting information and evidence to support your appeal. If you submit anything after the deadline, it might not be considered and may result in delays to your hearing. Families must be given at least  school days notice of the hearing. Appeals must be heard within  school days of the deadline for making an appeal. What happens at the appeal hearing   Appeal hearings are overseen by a  of three or more people. The  must be independent and follow the School Admission Appeals Code. At the hearing, the admission authority will explain why the application was turned down, and the parent will be given a chance to explain why their child should be admitted. Its up to the  to decide whether the school’s admission criteria were properly followed and comply with the code. If the criteria were not properly followed or do not comply with the school admissions code your appeal must be upheld, the Government says. It adds: If your reasons for your child to be admitted outweigh the school’s reasons for not admitting any more children at all, your appeal will be upheld. The decision is usually sent within five school days. Join waiting lists Parents who are advised to get on waiting lists for schools that they prefer, in case a place opens up between National Offer Day and the first day of term in September. To do that, contact the local authority or the school. The Government advises: If your child is on a waiting list and the school offers you a place, the admission authority will send you a formal offer. You can still accept the offer evenyour child has already started at another school. There is a shortage of places in some places. A  survey found a third of pupils in London did not get their first choice.

story: NewsShih-Tzu with thousands of flees couldnt even scratch itches due to matted furDavid Morris and his we Susan Morris from Grimsby are guilty of causing unnecessary sufferance to their dog FiShareCommentsByMark Naulor:,  MAR NewsThe dog was found to be so matted he couldnt even scratch his itches"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dog had to be clipped from head to toe after being found with thousands and thousands of flees and with such badly matted fur that he wasnt even able to scratch his itches. Fi, a male Shih-Tzu, was also found to have eye and skin problems when checked on by an RSPCA inspector at his home in Grisby.The dog may have been infested with the flees for up to two years in what his his vet said was the worst flee infection he had ever seen, Grimsby Live reports.Fi ultimately had to be put down due to an unrelated issue. David Morris, , and his we, Susan Morris, , of Southland Court, Grimsby, denied three offences of causing unnecessary suffering to a dog but were convicted after a trialNo veterinary help was called in - this could have been because the couple who owned the dog could not afford the cost of it, a court heard. In a tragic twist, he later had to be put down due to another problem. Gordon Holt, prosecuting for the RSPCA, told Grimsby magistrates that an inspector visited the couples home on January  last year and examined the dog, a Shih-Tzu aged nine or ten. Despite being male, it was called Fi.  The dogs fur was badly matted, it had a fleas infection and it had a dry eye problem. Those conditions were causing suffering to the dog, said Mr Holt. The owners should have taken the dog to a vet based on what they could see of its condition. There was clear evidence that there was suffering to this animal and it had been going on for some time, said Mr Holt. There were thousands and thousands of fleas and the infestation would have been there for about two years.  This dog was riddled with fleas, added Mr Holt.Police seized the dog and it was taken to the Blue Cross Animal Hospital, Grimsby , where a vet clipped it from head to toe to get rid of the matting.The dog would have been unable to scratch itches because of the matting and the flea bites would have been painful. The vet believed Fi had been caused unnecessary suffering, said Mr Holt. The vet said: I have never seen a flea infection that was so bad. Fleas were visible on every part of his body. Twenty fleas escaped from a square inch of the dogs skin and there were fleas around the eyes and neck.  The dog was put down six months later, in June, because of a suspected central nervous problem. David Morris later said of the dog: I rescued him off the street. I have had him six or seven years. I feel we have rescued Fi from certain death on the day I rescued him. I have not been cruel but possibly I have been stupid. I am bereftmy dog has suffered.Susan Morris claimed she did not notice the skin and eye conditions but bathed the dog sometimes for fleas.Defence barrister Hywel Davies claimed: There were no signs of discomfort or suffering. They were not to know. Nothing there warrants a trip to the vets. Ex-window cleaner David Morris, a trained nurse for  years, told the court that he found the stray dog on the streets.Part of the reason he did not alert a vet was that he feared that it would turn out to be microchipped and would be taken back to that awful place where he believed it had been cruelly treated. The prosecution claimed that the real reason was that the couple could not afford vets bills. He claimed that he did not see any eye or skin problems. I never noticed any problems, he said. I didnt think it was causing him any discomfort. It didnt seem to bother him. We knew there were fleas. We must have used every flea shampoo, flea powder that was available. If a new flea product came out, we used it. It seemed to reduce them to some extent. He didnt seem to be bothered by having them. He didnt whine and didnt scratch unduly. He just seemed a happy little dog. There was no cause for them to have concern about the dog suffering at any time. If he had, he would have been taken to a vet immediately, claimed Morris. I didnt think he was suffering in any way. Susan Morris told the court: He was just fine. I used to give him baths. I saw a few fleas on him but I was treating it, sometimes two, three times a week. It got better. He was just like a normal dog. He wasnt suffering at all. Sentence on the couple was adjourned for reports and they were allowed bail.

title: terry waite says shamima begum
story: NewsTerry Waite says Shamima Begum and her baby must be allowed toto UKThe former hostage was held captive between  and , and has now had his say on the debate about the ISIS brideShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  MAR NewsTerry Waite was chained, beaten and tortured by Hezbollah militants in Lebanon for nearly five years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNudging four score years and greying, Britain’s most famous hostage believes jihadi bride Shamima Begum and her newborn son must be allowed home. Bearded ft in giant Terry Waite is better placed than most to discuss forgiving someone groomed at  who ran away to join Islamic State in Syria. Hezbollah militants blindfolded, chained, beat and tortured him for nearly five years in neighbouring Lebanon. Despite never knowinghe’d live to see tomorrow between January  and November  – and enduring mock executions – Waite’s absence of malice towards his captors is how this former envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury treats most people.  And that includes the teenager from Bethnal Green, East London, enticed into a medieval theocratic death cult, then unfazed by the sight of severed heads. Waite is highly critical of the Home Secretary for banning Begum, removing the right to a passport of a young woman now a -year-old mother languishing in a Syrian refugee camp. “It was not a good or wise decision to revoke her UK citizenship,” asserts Waite. “This seems to me like a typical kneejerk reaction which is all too commonly followed by Government these days. “To declare the young woman stateless is, I believe, an action that is declared illegal in international law which we endorsed. This action is almost certain to be overturned and Britain will once again have lost credibility on the international stage. “It is my view that she ought to be subject to the law andit is found that she has broken that law then she should be subject to due process of the law.   “Thereafter she ought to be treated with compassion with regard to the fact that she is a young person who may well have been pressured into behaving as she did. “It goes without saying that I believe all iniduals who are convicted ought to be treated with compassion and understanding.” Sajid Javid’s gamble has backfired that Bangladesh, a country Begum has never visited or had a passport from, would take the marooned figure because of her parents’ links. The depth of public hostility towards her led to a Merseyside shooting range in Wallasey using a picture of the teenager’s shrouded head for target practice.  Yet Waite’s faith in the possibilities of redemption extend to the Islamic State teenager. But her crimes,any – Begum insists she was a housewe not a fighter – aren’t in the league of another woman who found a friend in Waite. The prison reformer befriended Myra Hindley, the notorious Moors Murderer. She was serial killer Ian Brady’s accomplice in the grisly slayings of five youngsters in the first half of the s. Hindley, often visited in jail by Waite before her death behind bars in , was, he believes, genuinely remorseful about her role in the horric crimes.  Her release, he thinks, was blocked because she’d been turned into an “icon of evil” by a haunting photograph and folk demanding vengeance. “I met with Myra Hindley,” recalls Waite, “who, as an emotional young woman, fell under the spell of a psychopath and then had the solitude of having to live with those terrible events. “She was demonised, definitely, and never freed for, I think, that simple reason.” Waite, reflective as he prepares to celebrate his th birthday in May, is speaking to me by video call from New Zealand. He stresses he offers “no excuses. Explanations, yes, but definitely no excuses” for Hindley’s involvement in the sexual abuse, torture and deaths of the five, then adds: “There have been people in prison who did equally terrible things and were released. “She had been made into an icon of evil. She used to say ‘I would like to get out and try again in le’ and I used to say ‘Myra, you would be in great danger because you have been made this icon of evil and someone will try to have a go’. “She said that was a chance she was willing to take.”  Waite first met jailed Hindley in Durham where she was held in the same block as serial killer Rose West, sentenced to the rest of her le in prison after she and husband Fred sexually assaulted and murdered at least  young women in their Gloucester home. He also talked to Hindley in Suffolk’s Highpoint Prison, visiting many times.In his book Solitude he noted she was sallow skinned, overweight, smoked heavily and suffered high blood pressure and osteoporosis.“I visited her many times across the years and, without in any way minimising her crimes, I am fairly confident the remorse she expressed on more than one occasion was genuine,” wrote Waite. “She had become a convert to Roman Catholicism in her youth and it was clear she had received considerable help from the RC prison chaplains, of whom she spoke most highly.” Waite never read the details of Brady and Hindley’s sadistic murders and intends never to do so. Theirs, he recognises, will go down in history as among the most terrible crimes in British history.  The parole she desired, he added, was never possible because infamy guaranteed no Home Secretary would ever sign papers to release her and she would’ve been a magnet for vigilantes. Conceding Hindley triggered hostility not sympathy, controversy doesn’t deter Waite. He rejects the “walking saint” tag when he displays considerable sympathy for people judged by the public, or found guilty by courts, of heinous offences. During his own captivity he’d try to cheer himself up by remembering travels with the Archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie. The journeys are revived in a republished, whimsical memoir, Travels with a Primate, projecting the good natured humour of a now elderly man who would have every right to resent his imprisonment but prefers to seek positives in everything and the goodness in everyone. “We need to look for the best in people and try to bring it out,” he says. The son of a Cheshire policeman, who ed to Beirut to forgive those who inflicted , days of hell, he has a house in Suffolk and collects clocks. At an age when many people put their feet up, he remains involved in a campaign against homelessness, advises iniduals and families who, like himself, find themselves in hostage situations and prison reform.  Waite maintains most people behaving badly, often incredibly badly, can and will be transformedwe put the emphasis on rehabilitation instead of locking them up in nightmare prisons. Quoting official figures warning nine in every  inmates suffer psychosis, depression, alcoholism, drug addiction and other problems, he’s convinced stopping men and women offending then reoffending would be beneficial for society as a whole. “Simply to put them in an institution where they have no hope is dreadful,” says Waite. “I can sympathise, I really can,you’re broken into and your house is trashed you’re going to be fed up. “Locking people up without hope isn’t helpful. I have experience of that, five years, I know how dficult it is not being able to do anything.” Demanding radical reform of prisons, ending degrading treatment in crumbling buildings, Waite is insistent he isn’t ignoring the impact burglaries, robberies, violence and murders have on victims and families. “I’m not being soft on crime. I must emphasise that,” he says. “I don’t like crime and I think it’s really something we must combat but having said that I believe in rehabilitation.” Terry Waite’s Travels with a Primate – Around the World with Robert Runcie is republished by SPCK. pound.

title: toddler human timebomb condition causes
story: NewsToddlers human timebomb condition makes her look like shes had a strokeAnya Behls parents left shocked as she let out a "terrible scream" and her eyes started to flicker in first episode at just  weeks oldShareCommentsByPaul Rodger:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsAnyas condition has been described as a human timebomb "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA toddler has been diagnosed with an incredibly rare human timebomb condition which causes stroke-like paralysis. Anya Behl suffers from Alternative Hemiplegia of Childhood , a neurological condition which is said to affect one in a million people. Her family are raising funds for groundbreaking gene therapy in the US. The -month-old tot experienced her first episode of AHC at  weeks old in October  and those with the lelong condition can be described as human timebombs.   Her parents Abhishek and Katherine say their lives changed forever when Anya let out a terrible scream as her eyes started to flicker - during her first episode of the condition. The couple, from Edinburgh, rushed Anya - who looked like she was having a stroke - to the Royal Hospital for Sick Children. Katherine, a hospital doctor, said they thought their daughter was going to die.   She said she knew what was going on medically - but as a mother, she felt helpless. After four months of tests and thinking that Anya was suffering from epilepsy, Katherine was told her daughter had the ATPA gene. The gene is responsible for around  per cent of AHC cases. Anya is one of only two children in Scotland with the condition and there are around  families in the UK living with it and only  worldwide.  According to the Alternative Hemiplegia of Childhood Foundation, the incidence of AHC is estimated at roughly one in ,, births. But they say the true incidence may be higher since the disorder is commonly misdiagnosed due to the lack of awareness about AHC. Katherine said her daughters condition has taken an emotional toll on the family, with her husband quitting his job as a travel consultant to look after Anya full time.   She said: We just have to live truly in the moment and enjoy a good hour or good day or even enjoy her being able to eat breakfast without paralysis or distress rather than think of the whole picture. At first we used to get anxious waiting for the next episode to hit not knowing what might come but we realised it wasnt sustainable to live like that. We are grateful for the moments she is well and her happy self and try not to focus on it changing in a second. We know how fragile le can be. She added: It doesnt ever leave you though and it influences every single thing we do. Even days out with their young daughter involve stringent preparation in case a seizure takes place. Katherine said: We dont leave home without her emergency medications. Our nappy bag includes her emergency meds and a paediatric face mask should we need to help support her airwayit affects her breathing.   When shes paralysed down one side, but not in her worst case, its heartbreaking to see her try to crawl when she cant balance unable to move one side or support herself. In  months at least one of us - my husband or I - have been with her   except for one hour when my mum looked after her and constantly watching her as her condition can change in a second. Now the couple is hoping to raise funds for a groundbreaking gene therapy project in the US. The pair have launched an Anya is a One in a Million fundraising campaign on their JustGiving page which has raised over pound, of a pound, target.  The money will go towards a pre-clinical, non-human trial to be conducted with the support of several AHC foundations in the US. The trial is essential before ethical approval can be sought with a view to testing the gene therapy in humans. Katherine said: Despite starting  with Anya in and out of paralysis, distress and a host of neurological symptoms, we now have real hope for advancements in AHC research. Anyas JustGiving page can be found here .

story: NewsCaptured Indian pilot to get heros welcome as hes handed over by PakistanWing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman of Indias air force was captured by Pakistan amid escalating tensions in the disputed border region of KashmirShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video footage-emerges-appearing-show-indian-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn Indian air force pilot who was captured by Pakistan after his jet was shot down is set to be handed over at the border, with India planning a heros welcome amid heavy security. Wing Commander Abhinandan Varthaman was captured by Pakistans army as the nuclear powers exchanged tit-for-tat air strikes and shellfire amid escalating tensions in the disputed Kashmir regions. The pilot was beaten by a mob after his plane went down, leaving him bloodied, and then blindfolded and paraded on video by Pakistans army. Pakistans Prime Minister Imran Khan, the former cricketer, announced on Thursday that the captured pilot would be ed to India as gesture of peace as he attempted to de-escalate the crisis. He said Pakistan wants peace and stability in the region, but warned that it would be forced to retaliateIndia acted aggressively.   Pakistans Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi confirmed to lawmakers on Friday that the pilot will be handed over to Indian authorities at the Wagah border crossing. Mr Qureshi told parliament: As a gesture of peace and to de-escalate matters, the Indian pilot who is under arrest with us will be released today in the afternoon at the Wagah border. The border crossing, known for its daily ceremony involving Indian and Pakistani security forces, is near Pakistans eastern city of Lahore.   Wing Commander Varthaman was captured on Wednesday after his MiG- Bison jet was shot down. Indian media have called him a national hero and hes expected to receive an enthusiastic welcome from senior air force officials and local residents as he s to India. Crowds of locals began gathering on Indias side of the border checkpoint at am local time, hoping to catch a glimpse of the pilot, and by pm hundreds of people were present. They sang patriotic songs, waved the Indian flag and held up signs, and one group was holding a giant garland that they hoped to place around the pilots neck.  Wing Commander Varthaman is likely to be handed over first to the International Committee of Red Cross under rules of the Geneva Convention and then to air force officials before flying to Delhi, Indian media reported. He will reunite with his family and be debriefed by defence and security officials once he s to India. Footage shows the pilots parents being cheered and applauded on a plane at Delhi airport on Thursday evening. Fellow passengers gave way and allowed them to disembark first after they flew from Chennai to Delhi to wait for their sons . Meanwhile, shellfire continued in the disputed border region as world leaders called for restraint amid fears that the crisis could escalate even further and lead to a new war between the old adversaries.

The Symphony of the Seas ship was docked at Nassau port, and passengers had been given an all-aboard time of .pm. At .pm, the gangway was removed and doors were closed – the couple arrived five minutes later. Footage of the couple running desperately for the ship was then shared across the world.  The video, taken from the neighbouring Norwegian Bliss cruise liner, shows them arrive, run to the front of the ship and converse with workers onboard, who presumably told them it was too late. The clip shows the pair waving their arms in hopes the ship would stop, and desperate screams of “No!” can be heard from as the vessel moves away. story: NewsExtremely rare semi-identical twins born in Australia leaving doctors stunnedThe brother and sister were born from one egg and fertilised by two sperm, which then splitShareCommentsBySally Wardle:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video what-twin-twin-transfusion-syndrome-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Extremely rare semi-identical twins have been born in Australia in the second case to ever be recorded. The four-year-old brother and sister, from Brisbane, share all of their mothers DNA but only a proportion of their fathers, according to a report in The New England Journal of Medicine.They were first identied as semi-identical, or sesquizygotic, using genetic testing while still in the womb. Professor Nicholas Fisk, who led the team that cared for the mother and twins at the Royal Brisbane and Womens Hospital in , said it was an exceptional case. It is likely the mothers egg was fertilised simultaneously by two of the fathers sperm before iding, he said.   The mothers ultrasound at six weeks showed a single placenta and positioning of amniotic sacs that indicated she was expecting identical twins. However, an ultrasound at  weeks showed the twins were male and female, which is not possible for identical twins. Identical twins develop when cells from a single egg, fertilised by a single sperm, ide into two. This means they share identical DNA and are the same sex. Non-identical twins occur when the two babies develop at the same time from separate eggs and separate sperm. Semi-identical twins come from one egg, fertilised by two sperm, which then split.   This type of fertilisation results in three sets of chromosomes. Dr Michael Gabbett, from Queensland University of Technology, said: Three sets of chromosomes are typically incompatible with le and embryos do not usually survive. In the case of the Brisbane sesquizygotic twins, the fertilised egg appears to have equally ided up the three sets of chromosomes into groups of cells which then split into two, creating the twins. Some of the cells contain the chromosomes from the first sperm while the remaining cells contain chromosomes from the second sperm, resulting in the twins sharing only a proportion rather % of the same paternal DNA. Semi-identical twins were first reported in the US in , but only came to the attention of doctors during their infancy.

Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness College students showcase work of Highland Hospice
story: DRAMA students at Inverness College UHI have teamed up with Highland Hospice to offer insight into the patient experience of palliative care.Third year BAdrama and performance students performed Homeward Bound, a -minute play charting one couplersquos experience of end-of-le care, after being approached by the hospice.Officials at the hospice were keen to see live drama used as an educational tool to help improve the quality of palliative care and the experience of those involved.The play was performed to staff and nursing and care students at the college, with hospice representatives providing commentary to provide context and insight into the experience.It proved such a useful educational tool, the drama students have been asked to perform the play again at the NHS Highland Highland Hospice Essentials in Palliative Care Conference at Eden Court in Inverness, on March -, where it will be filmed to be used in learning.Lesley Mickel, programme leader for the drama course, said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with Highland Hospice to develop this special performance, which really highlights the human impact of late diagnosis and the importance of quality palliative care.ldquoIt was not only a challenge for our students in terms of portraying these very raw, human emotions, it also proved an extremely useful educational tool for students studying other parts of the university curriculum, with our nursing and care students gaining a much greater understanding of the issues involved.Hospice learning and development practice lead Siobhan Neylon said: ldquoIt was such an honour to work with these wonderful students on this poignant and emotive drama.ldquoThey portrayed the characters in such a dignied way.Homeward Bound was written by playwright Brian Daniels and tells the true story of Lesley and her husband Seth Goodburn, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer at the age of . He died just  days after diagnosis.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Inverness pupils donate money to city cycling charity
story: PUPILS at an Inverness secondary school have selected a charity which provides cycle outings for the elderly to receive pound in funding from the Young Philanthropy Initiative .The scheme is sponsored by the Aberdeen-based Wood Foundation and students in each school were asked to make presentations to fellow students and a  of judges who selected the winning team which had a chosen charity.Millburn Academy have donated their money to Cycling Without Age, Inverness ndash a charity with specially adapted bikes which takes residents from care homes and Highland Hospice on rides around the town and local countryside.Alice Munro, principal teacher of English, said the competition was a great experience for the pupils.ldquoThey invited people from ious charities to the school and went out to see the work these charities do in the local community. After their research, teams were asked to give a presentation and the judges were former staff members, the school chaplain and a police representative.ldquoThe winning charity, Cycling Without Age, is a fantastic organisation doing great work with the elderly in the community.Cycling Without Age spokesman Mick Heath said: ldquoIt began as an idea in the head of Dr Katie Walter of Cairn Medical Practice.ldquoShe recruited me to be her helper. It all began with a chance encounter in July .ldquoWe started networking and soon had a grant from HiTrans Active Travel to buy our first electric trike for taking the elderly and frail out for rides.ldquoWe were quickly joined by Dr Moira Finlayson and we three have been going at it flat out since then.The charity now has four trikes and several volunteer pilots and has taken more than  passengers on more than  rides.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Opinion divided on how to tackle Inverness gull menace
story: TIDY streets could be a more effective deterrent to Invernessrsquos seagull menace than culling, according to the RSPB.The suggestion comes in response to a call for a limited cull by city businessman Charlie Barbour.Mr Barbour, who owns city centre bars The White House and The Dog House as well as commercial property agency Barbour Commercial, suggests that destroying a small number of nesting pairs would make the centre of Inverness more attractive, safer and quieter.Describing the birds as ldquonoisy, dirty, aggressive and a blight on the city centre, Mr Barbour questions whether the Inverness Business Improvement Districtpolicy of removing eggs each year is enough to permanently reduce the gull population.ldquoWhilst a cull of such birds is not a universally popular decision, I just wonderthere is merit in destroying say three or four nesting pairs of seagulls each year, he writes.ldquoA reduction in seagull numbers would improve the city centre experience for visitors and that surely has to be a good thing However, a spokeswoman for conservation charity the RSPB said that lethal control should only ever be a last resort, used only where there is a proven problem and other alternatives have proven ineffective. Instead, local authorities, businesses and iniduals should tackle the problem by reducing the birdsrsquo food supply by cutting down the amount of edible litter and introducing gull-proof litter bins.Other non-lethal options include putting up physical barriers such as netting on roofs as a deterrent before the breeding season.ldquoWe believe that gull problems in an urban environment are best tackled by reducing the availability of food and nest sites. If the features that attract gulls remain, any `vacanciesrsquo created by controlling existing gulls will simply be filled by other gulls moving in, she said.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Friday  Mar  : AM

title: Success sees Inverness Town House tours extended
story: POPULARITY has prompted the number of guided tours of Inverness Town House to double this summer.City councillors have agreed to add two more tours each week after positive feedback.The tours were introduced in June in a move which completed a so-called cultural triangle which includes the cityrsquos museum and Inverness Castle Viewpoint.Two tours on Thursdays have been run by High Le Highlandand proved logistically and financially viable ndash making a pound. profit ndash with the additional two tours on Tuesdays starting on from May .Tours have not disrupted any business in the building and visitors have found them engaging, informative and entertaining.Inverness provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoWell done to High Le Highland and in particular their team of guides, who helped the council create a third, new, visitor attraction in the town house, which along with the museum and art gallery and castle viewpoint have created an accessible lsquocultural trianglersquo around the Castle Wynd area.ldquoAs we move towards the redevelopment of Inverness Castle as a new lsquomust-seersquo visitor attraction, the Town House Tours will complement the tourism offering in this city centre location.HLH chief executive Ian Murray said: ldquoHigh Le Highland has been delighted to work with the council to create public access to the splendid town house and we look forward to seeing visitor numbers and tour provision increasing this summer.Friday  Mar  : AM

story: Boss Derek McInnes today demanded the Dons get aggressive in their Scottish Cup clash with Rangers.McInnes was frustrated at the lack of dig from the Reds as their dismal home form continued with a - loss to relegation- battling Hamilton.He has warned that fight mustfor the Pittodrie quarter-final with the Gers.Aberdeen go into the cup tie amid a concerning home slump with just two points from the last .McInnes warned Aberdeen’s season hinges on solving their home hurt against an in-form Rangers side that has hit  goals in three games.Aberdeen also suffered an injury blow with left back Max Lowe coming off injured and he will be a doubt for the cup tie.McInnes said: “There has to be more aggression in our game from the start.“We cannot just pick and choose when that aggression comes.“It has to be there in every game, certainly the game against Rangers will demand it.“There is no doubt our home form has to improve for us to achieve what we want to achieve.“Certainly now on Sunday going into the cup gamewe want to make sure we are in with a chance of winning a cup and get into the semi-final we have to make sure there is more aggression in our performance.“Against Hamilton while there was no shortage of effort there was a shortage of aggression and confidence, especially once the second goal went in.“We are all responsible and we should all expect better.“It looked to me that Hamilton were the team with the biggest cause.“That shouldn’t be the case as we want to do as well as we can.“That was the most disappointing thing.”Aberdeen have taken just one point from back to back home games against the Premiership’s bottom sides, St Mirren and Hamilton.They were held - to bottom outfit St Mirren in the previous match at Pittodrie.Amidst the home slump since the turn of the year the Dons also drew - with Stenhousemuir, the team bottom of League One, in cup action.McInnes apologized to fans for another home howler.He said: “I am bitterly disappointed as we should all expect more from an Aberdeen team.“The supporters should expect more from ourselves.“We expect far more from ourselves.“We can only apologize to the supporters for the level of performance.“There is a demand here and you have to deal with that and we have for the last six years.“We want players who are brave enough to get on the ball whether it is - or we are behind.“While still having the confident to make things happen and we were miles away from that in terms of taking that responsibility.“I think the players are honest enough andthey are honest enough with themselves they will say they fell way short of what is expected.”Aberdeen’s defensive jinx struck yet again as on loan Derby County left-back Max Lowe had to leave the pitch injured after just  minutes.That came less than  hours after the Dons secured Greg Halford from the free agent market as emergency cover to strengthen the defence.Halford has previously played for Sunderland, Wolves and Cardf City – he was an unused substitute against Hamilton.Defender Halford, , was signed in reaction to the injuries to right back Shaleum Logan and on loan Watford defender Tommie Hoban.Logan is out for two to three months having undergone ankle surgery.Hoban is set to undergo cruciate ligament surgery and is out for the season.On Lowe, McInnes said: “It was enough for him to come off which puts him in doubt for Sunday.”Hamilton went ahead in the first half with a magnicent goal from George Oakley from near the byline.They secured the points to move them further clear of the immediate relegation spot through Mickel Miller in the second half.McInnes said: “I have got to praise Hamilton for their part in it as they played well.“The team with the more aggression won the game.“It is a reminder to my players that while there is plenty of effort and running about you cannot just win a game based on your quality.“There are so many other factors needed to win a game.“We were unconvincing from the off in terms of defending and gave them one or two opportunities to keep them interested.“The last  minutes of the first half we played well and were unfortunate not to get the equalizer.“We asked the players to go and deliver a second half full of confidence with more aggression and intent.“We got that for spells at the start of the second half and passed up a few chances.“There were enough chances to win the game, that is clear.”

title: campaigners calling for return of gatwick flights welcome new aberdeen connection
story: Campaigners have welcomed the arrival of a new air link between Aberdeen and the south of England.Loganair will operate a new three-times-a-day service between the north-east and London Southend from May .Airline launches new Aberdeen-London Southend flights" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp news local airline-launches-aberdeen-london-southend-flights embed # secretcOPyfbsO" data-secret"cOPyfbsO" width"" "" title"#Airline launches new Aberdeen-London Southend flights# # Evening Express" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"The move means passengers will be able to travel from Aberdeen into the centre of London in less than two-and-a-half hours.Val Fry, who started a petition after the city’s Gatwick service was withdrawn earlier this month, believes the new route will make the south-east more accessible.She said: “It’s great news that a new route is coming because recently it has seemed like everything is being withdrawn.“It’s fantastic to see a new destination and it’s great that someone is doing something to open Aberdeen up again.“Southend makes that side of London and the south-east accessible, and the fact it’s three times a day is great too.“I think it’s fantastic news. The more routes coming into Aberdeen the better.”The journey to Essex will take just over  minutes, with a further -minute train journey into London Liverpool Street.Loganair’s managing director Jonathan Hinckles said: “We’re acutely aware of the limited options for London air travel from Aberdeen following the closure of the Gatwick route and have responded to the Aberdeen business community’s calls for improved air links by stepping into the gap left behind.”Aberdeen International Airport managing director Steve Szalay added: “Regional connectivity to London is essential to Aberdeen for both business and leisure and London Southend offers a new alternative for our passengers.“The beauty of the new London Southend service lies in the ease of access to central London.“With train services to Liverpool Street taking less than an hour, passengers can reach the heart of London in quick time and get their trip off to the best possible start.”

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: honours even for red star in argyll derby

The game continued at a frantic pace, however, there was no further scoring in the first half and Star went in with a - advantage.Pupils came out with purpose in the second half as they looked to force themselves back into the game, however, it was a howler from Red Star which allowed them back into the match.A square ball across the back resulted in a mix-up between Star keeper Luke Kalache and defender Ben Forbes which allowed Donald McCallum to prod the ball home from just inside the box and Pupils were back in the game at - with eight second half minutes gone.The home side didn’t recover from this and you could sense a nervousness that gave the visitors plenty encouragement. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: hourstons closes ayr last independent
story: NewsHourstons closes in Ayr as last independent department store shuts up shop todayThe last independent bastion of the High Street is closing today with a giant clear-out taking place.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsLeg-end - show is over for Hourstons "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr’s last independent department store closes at pm tonight – but not before a giant clear-out. General manager Linda Lawson will pay tribute to  staff, who are all losing their jobs. And absolutely everything that could earn a pound was sold – including old mannequins , fashion stands and even store room shelving. The massive clear-out included giving away box loads of coat hangers. The building closes after  years of trading after current multi-millionaire owners the Jebreel family pulled the rug. As stock was snapped up in the sale, staff turned to fixtures and fittings to sell. Eight mannequins at pound each were snapped up - and some will remain gracing town windows. The building itself is now up for sale at offers over pound, but it is impossible to think it will ever operate as a single unit again. Staff are wanting to bow out quietly and didn’t want to line-up for an official “last photo” for the Ayrshire Post. MSP John Scott described the loss to the town as a “hammer blow.” Hourstons – and then Arnotts under House of Fraser control – has been one of Ayr’s retail institutions since the s. Orcadian David Hourston first opened a shop in Kyle Street before building the present store in . On David’s death in , his sons took over the business which had become one of the largest retail drapery establishments in Scotland. Its tearooms, smoking rooms and roof gardens became famed across the country. In April  the business was acquired by the House of Fraser group and in the years following, ious changes took place, both in nameand in ownership. Hourstons Ltd was formed in  by Isaac and Helen Jebreel of Hampstead, London. The store’s Facebook site says: “Hourstonshas been a retail beacon on the high street for generations, everyone has a story or memory in connection with the place” Shoppers shared their memories on its Facebook site this week. Sharon Johnstone said: “My uncle Bob was your restaurant manager years ago. “There was the wee lady in the lt, Santa, and many more lovely memories. “Hourstons will never be forgotten as long as there are mums and grannys still saying, “look at the state of you, I couldn’t dress you in Hourstons window!”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnFacebookLawsonAyrSocial mediaAyr News

title: hydro power set earn cash
story: NewsHydro power set to earn cash from the River AyrA water-driven turbine is set to generate power from river flowShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsWeve got the power - how the turbine will operate "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA cash generating hydro turbine delayed for more than three years seems set to happen at last. The pound million screw will be positioned right on the old mill weir on the River Ayr opposite Ayrshire College. The weir originally drove an old cornmill on the site. Now tens of thousands of pounds a year will be generated by the flow of the river. Updated plans are now being considered by South Ayrshire Council, which is behind the scheme through the local Energy Agency. They show a single archimedes screw turbine at the old Nethermills Weir. Consultants Mann Power Hydro say: “Completion of this project will create a supply of renewable energy into the local distribution network, proposing firstly to sell the majority of output locally to meet the electricity demands of Ayrshire College, where the grid connection will be made. “In mitigation, the project includes a historic improvement to the passage of eels, lampreys and salmon smolts at the weir by the provision of new specialised passes for these species, and also improves upstream and downstream migration for salmon and other fish species. “It will moderate the flows into the existing passes in some conditions, which will make these less challenging. “This will help ameliorate a general problem whereby a weir is a barrier to migration of fish.” It is predicted the turbine - more than  feet in diameter and  feet long - will generate up to  kilowatts per year. The blade will turn at a maximum  revolutions per minute The Energy Agency carried out a study last year to estimate the energy potential passing over the weirs at Nethermills. It is expected the council will pocket pound, a year from selling the power and the scheme would receive a pound, feed-in-tarf. The single four-bladed screw is enough to power  homes. A report said: “With proper maintenance the scheme should continue to generate clean power for many decades after its capital cost has been repaid. “The scheme would provide an eye-catching and interesting landmark in the middle of the town, an emblem of the community’s dedication to the principle of sustainable development. A decision on approval is expected shortly.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyrAyr NewsEnvironmentScottish rivers
